Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Situation2: A routine service is held, and attendance numbers are usually sufficient even if one person is absent.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the hum of the office fading as my mind wandered. The project was still in its early stages, nothing set in stone, but my manager wanted me to join a brainstorming session tonight—an opportunity to pitch new ideas, to shape the direction from the ground up. As an engineer, I felt the pull of responsibility, the excitement of possibility, and the unspoken expectation to be present, to contribute.

But tonight was also the regular synagogue service. I’d promised myself to attend consistently, to be part of the community, to honor my faith. Even though the minyan would likely have enough people without me, I knew my absence would be noticed by a few, and I’d feel the weight of missing out on something meaningful, something grounding.

I stared at my calendar, the two events overlapping. The pressure built inside me—my professional drive clashing with my spiritual commitment. I wanted to be both the reliable engineer and the devoted Jew, but tonight, I couldn’t be in two places at once. My hands trembled slightly as I weighed the expectations, feeling the tension coil tighter with every passing minute.
